headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to the FPL Group Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Rebecca Kiaba. Please
componenttext: Good day, everyone and welcome to the FPL Group Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Rebecca Kiaba. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Donnie. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2009 earnings conference call. Lew Hay, FPL Group Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, will provide an overview of FPL Group's performance and recent accomplishment
componenttext: Thank you, Donnie. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year 2009 earnings conference call. Lew Hay, FPL Group Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, will provide an overview of FPL Group's performance and recent accomplishment. Lew will be followed by Armando Pimentel, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the specifics of our financial results.Also joining us this morning are Jim Robo, President and Chief Operating Officer of FPL Group; Armando Olivera, President and CEO of Florida Power & Light; and Mitch Davidson, President and Chief Executive Officer of NextEra Energy Resources. Following our prepared remarks, our senior management team will be available to take your questions.We will be making statements during this call that are forward-looking. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Certain key assumptions, on which our financial outlook and wind generation outlook are based, are highlighted in the appendix to the accompanying presentation.Actual results could differ materially from our forward-looking statements if any of these key assumptions are incorrect or because of other factors discussed in today's earnings press release and the comments made during this conference call in the Risk Factors section of the accompanying presentation or in our latest reports and filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, each of which can be found in the Investors section of our website www.FPLGroup.com. We do not undertake any duty to update any forward-looking statements.Please note also that today's presentation includes references to adjusted earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. You should refer to the information contained in the slides accompanying this presentation for definitional information and reconciliations of the non-GAAP measure to the closest GAAP financial measure. And now I would like to turn the call over to Lew Hay.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you Rebecca and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that despite some significant challenges, FPL Group grew adjusted earnings per share by more than 5% in 2009 and continued its strong long streak of strong returns on equity by the earnin
componenttext: Thank you Rebecca and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that despite some significant challenges, FPL Group grew adjusted earnings per share by more than 5% in 2009 and continued its strong long streak of strong returns on equity by the earning 13.5% adjusted ROE. NextEra Energy Resources 2009 was another year of record adjusted earnings per share which grew by approximately 6% over 2008. The key drivers were new win projects and strong performance by our wholesale marketing and trading business and our Texas retail business. This strong economic performance occurred despite the expense outage at our Seabrook nuclear plant a polar wind resource of gross across our fleet of nearly 9000 turbines and unfavorable market conditions in Texas region. At Florida Power & Light come up for your earnings were approximately 4% per share principal drivers were favorable weather conditions during much of the year and completion of two generating units at our West County Energy Center in Palm Beach County which allowed for base rate adjustment under the Generation Base Rate Adjustment mechanism.These drivers were partially offset by the continuing effects of the fragile Florida economy including flat customer growth and weak underlying usage. For the fourth quarter of 2009, FPL Group's adjusted earnings were $323 million compared to $361 million in the prior-year quarter. As were the case for the full year, the most significant drivers were the outages at our Seabrook nuclear plant and exceptionally weak wind resource somewhat offset by higher than expected weather related usage in Florida.The outages at our Seabrook plant alone negatively affected earnings by $0.13. In addition, we are continuing to experience an El Ni√±o influenced weather pattern which we believe partially explains the reduction in short-term wind resources across Texas and the Midwest.Over the long-term, we remain confident in our wind resource projections. Armando will discuss zebra cottage in our wind resource analysis in more detail in a few moments.Although we are our 2009 adjusted earnings did not meet our original expectations we had a number of accomplishments during the year that should provide long-term benefits to our stakeholders. For example, our twin 1,220-megawatt combined cycle generating units at the West County Energy Center will increase the efficiency of FPL's generation lead providing savings the customer from slow cost reductions over the life of the projects and reduce emissions.In addition, with President Obama in attendance, FPL in October commissioned the DeSoto Next Generation Solar Energy Center, the largest solar photovoltaic power plant in the United States. Construction also began on FPL's Martin and Space Coast Next Generation Solar Energy Center which was slated to open this year. I think in no FPL will cover the cost of these projects under a Florida statute enacted to encourage renewable energy projects.Operationally, FPL's fossil fuel fleet reached a record level of efficiency in 2009. FPL's investment since 2002 in cleaner more efficient technology avoided approximately 4.9 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions in 2009 and saved customers an estimated $440 million in fuel costs during the year.No less important are FPL's efforts to prudently manage cost. For all of 2009, FPL's O&M expenses were $1.42 per kilowatt hour. Industry as whole over them expenses were $2.11 per kilowatt hour as of 2008, the most recent data available. NPL's efficiency is matched by its reliability with the company's assisted average interruption duration index is up 47% better than the national average.NextEra Energy Resources, we added approximately 1,170 megawatts of wind capacity in North America in 2009. We now own 7,540 megawatts of wind capacity in 17 states in Canada, maintaining our position as North America's wind energy leader. Today, our total investment in wind is approximately $11 billion.In addition, you've heard me say before that we hope solar will be the next wind business in next energy resources. And that strategy has started to bear fruit in 2009. In October, we found large long-term power purchase agreement with Pacific Gas and Electric Company for the sale of 250-megawatt solar thermal power from our proposed Genesis Solar Energy Project. This plant would use the same basic technology we have mastered at our existing solar arrays in California.The Genesis project is expected to produce enough renewable electricity to power more than 80,000 homes while creating jobs and a positive economic impact for California's Riverside County.Also during the year, we completed a roughly 200-mile generation timeline linking some of our West Texas wind assets to the more favorable South Texas zone. And we continued to prudently grow our wholesale marketing and trading business in conjunction with the growth of next year generation business.And lastly, we were able to finance the growth of our portfolio on a primarily nonrecourse base during the year, the especially difficult financing environment that prevailed for much of the year. It is attributed to the quality of our deal that they were able to meet the market test for finance ability by a third-party.Overall, we were able to raise approximately $1.1 million billion in project financing during the last 12 or so months.Let me spend a moment on the outcome of our rate proceedings before the Florida Public Service Commission which as you know from our prior comments was extremely disappointing to us. We'll get into some of the details of the commission's decision later on the call but as you know, the decision caused us to suspend some of our large capital expenditure projects pending further review.As I said immediately after the commissioners concluded our rate case, historically Florida has been constructive regulatory environment which is provided benefits to both customers and investors. This historically favorable environment has allowed us to invest billions of dollars to benefit Florida FPL customers were having reasonable confidence that our investors will be allowed to earn their returns.While the proceedings of two weeks ago clearly indicates that the situation has changed, we need to be mindful that the poor economic climate in Florida has significantly impacted our customers and the political environment. And this in turn affected our rate proceedings including the ultimate outcome.I remain optimistic that as the Florida economy improves, and as we do a better job telling our story, the regulatory climate will improve. Now despite the setback, I want to remind you that we continue to have certain attractive elements to our regulatory structure including clauses for fuel, energy efficiency and environmental cost. We also have immediate increases to rates in our new solar projects and our nuclear upgrades and cost recovery from new nuclear development in latency costs.Over the long-term, I continue to be optimistic about Florida's prospects. Our state has historically been one of the fastest-growing in the nation. With good weather, no state income taxes, and affordable housing, combined with the baby boomers starting to reach retirement age, we believe that Florida should return to strong growth.Now what I'm most disappointed about our rate case is that the company with the lowest rates of the State's 54 utilities, reliability that is 47% better than the national average, and power generation that is among the cleanest and most efficient in the country, namely Florida Power & Light, was granted the lowest ROE among the investor owned in 2009. This type of performance should be rewarded, not penalized.Never be disappointment must was not getting cost recovery progressed on the Unit 3 which is expected to go into service in mid-2011. This plant represents an investment of $865 million, for which we will get the return until we find another rate request. Either a limited scope rate case as has been suggested by one commissioner or a full-fledged case such as the one we just completed.Again, I don't think this is good regulatory policy either as likely put a dampen on future investment.Clearly, we need to do some things differently in response to the PSC's decision. We've already announced that we suspended for the time being our efforts on several large capital projects. And I emphasized the word suspend as opposed to the word canceled. These are significant projects that we ultimately hope to build and operate but the decision to suspend them were made in response to the negative impact negative decision NPL's creditworthiness and its ability to attract capital at attractive rates.honestly preserving FPL's credit rating is important to the customer rates low and for maintaining access to the capital markets. Our efforts to offset the negative impact of the rate decision on FPL's credit worthiness will necessarily involve reductions in capital spending, a point we repeatedly made throughout the period of the rate proceedings.As a result, we are reviewing our capital expenditure program to determine what changes we should meet our current capital plans. In doing so, we will carefully examine the impact of any potential changes on reserve margins, customer rates, reliability as well as the company's credit worthiness. Our review of major projects will also consider factors that may have changed his original investment decisions were made, including low growth estimates, fuel cost forecast, demand management requirements and environmental advances.It is important to note that we are continuing to invest in Florida's electrical infrastructure. Last year, our capital expenditures were $2.5 billion. And this year, despite suspending certain projects, we are still expecting to invest $22.4 billion, which is well in excess of FPL's cash generation.Is one commissioner noted, we are going to have to and I quote, "tighten our belt." This will be difficult given that our own M-cost per kilowatt hour are already 33% below the industry's 2008 average. Anything we do has to pass the test of not affecting customer service, safety or reliability.Our last full-fledged rate case was about 35 years ago. I think it's safe to say that we cannot go another five years without filing another rate case but we have not decided when we will do so again. We also need to work in communicating our messages better and being more in touch with all of our constituents in Florida. There is a lot we can learn from this experience and I assure you we will.We are currently undergoing a thorough review of FPL's operation and capital plans including the suspended projects. We intend to discuss these plans with investors and other constituents no later than the end of the second quarter.Finally, despite the setback at FPL, we expect decent growth in FPL Group 2010. Amanda will fill you in on the details when he discusses our updated guidance for 2010. And with that I will turn the call over to Armando Pimentel before returning for a few final remarks. Armando?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lew and good morning everyone. In the fourth quarter of 2009, FPL Group's GAAP net income results were $349 million or $0.85 per share compared to $408 million or $1.01 per share during the fourth quarter of 2008. FPL Group's adjusted 2009 four
componenttext: Thank you, Lew and good morning everyone. In the fourth quarter of 2009, FPL Group's GAAP net income results were $349 million or $0.85 per share compared to $408 million or $1.01 per share during the fourth quarter of 2008. FPL Group's adjusted 2009 fourth quarter earnings and EPS were $323 million and $0.79 respectively compared to $351 million or $0.19 per share in 2008.for the full year 2009 come FPL Group's GAAP net income results were $1.6 billion or $3.79 per share compared to $1.6 billion or $4.07 per share in 2008. FPL Group's adjusted 2009 earnings and EPS were $1.6 billion and $4.05 respectively compared with $1.5 billion or $3.84 per share in 2008.The difference between the GAAP results and the adjusted results is the exclusion of the mark in our non-qualifying hedge category and the exclusion of the net other than temporary impairments or OTTI.As you're well aware, whether has an impact on many of our businesses and in 2009 its effect was significant. The diversity of our company's operations in terms of geography, fuel and other factors means that weather may have offsetting impacts across our portfolio as was somewhat the case in 2009. This slide shows the fourth and full year 2000 results of actual weather both compared to the prior periods and to normal.In 2009, whether had a positive impact on Florida Power & Light's results for having an overall, negative impact on the portfolio of NextEra Energy Resources. In the fourth quarter alone, weather compared to normal was $0.05 lower than expected. Florida Power & Light's 2009 results were higher than we were expecting when we began the year although part of the improvement is due to favorable weather conditions. Fourth quarter 2009 earnings at Florida Power & Light were $186 million up 23% from $151 million a year ago. The corresponding earnings-per-share contribution was $0.45 this year versus $0.38 in 2008.Full year 2009 earnings were $831 million, up 5% from $789 million a year ago. The corresponding earnings-per-share contribution was $2.04 per share this year versus $1.96 per share in 2008. Based on preliminary data, the 12 month average regulatory ROE ending December 30, 2009 was 10.1%.Although we realized strong kilowatt hour sales growth in the fourth quarter, we caution investors that the underlying trends that drive our business remain weak. As you know, we monitor a number of economic and usage indicators to gauge the economic health of Florida in general and our customers in particular.The table in the upper left shows the change in retail kilowatt hour sales versus last year's comparable period. Overall, retail kilowatt hour sales grew by 7.7%, an improvement due solely to higher weather-related usage.Usage growth due to weather helped the quarterly earnings comparisons by approximately $0.10 per share. For the full year, weather contributed $0.14 per share relative to the prior year.The right-hand graph at the top shows sequential changes in our quarterly customer accounts. Although there is a seasonal component to our customer base, the silent customer count grew slightly in the quarter. The graph in the bottom left-hand corner of this page shows inactive and low usage customers which we believe depict the level of empty homes in our service territory. Since year-end 2007, the number of inactive account as increased by about 68,000 to approximately 312,000 with most of that increase occurring in 2008.However, since the end of the third quarter, both the number of inactive and number of low usage customers have declined for the first time since 2007.The chart on the bottom right depicts a year-over-year change in housing starts for single family homes in FPL service territory. Housing starts are a fairly good leading indicator of additions to our customer base roughly a year out. As we have discussed, much of Florida's economic lows have been directly tied to the housing industry. After a prolonged period of decline, by the end of 2009, we actually saw some growth in housing starts. It is clearly too early to say that this is a long-term trend but we are encouraged by the increase in activity over the last couple of months.In sum, the general economic environment in Florida remains challenging and the outlook remains uncertain. The 11.8% unemployment rate in December is the highest unemployment rate in Florida since May, 1975. For comparison, the Florida unemployment rate was 11.1% in September and 8.8% in January, 2009.The table shown here summarizes the earnings drivers for Florida Power & Light for the just completed quarter as well as for the full year 2009. In total, the quarterly comparison increased by $0.07 per share driven primarily by favorable weather conditions and the rate adjustment for West County Units 1 and 2. These are partially offset by a higher O&M and depreciation expenses. Full year 2009 results were driven by favorable weather conditions and the addition of West County Units 1 and 2 partially offset by lower underlying usage and the higher O&M and depreciation expenses.After a very lengthy process, on January 13, the Florida Public Service Commission reached a decision on the revenue requirements portion of our rate increase request. There were approximately 170 individual issues that the commission had to decide but I will discuss only a handful of this with you today.Our adjusted regulatory equity ratio which is 59% of total sources of capital including short and long-term debt, was approved by the commission. This is the actual amount of equity that we have in the business today and is what we requested in our filings. The equity ratio when compared to all sources of regulatory capital, including customer deposits, and deferred taxes, is 47%.The commission authorize regulatory return on equity of 10% plus or minus 100 basis points. Importantly, this also affects the return we earn on investments recovered through environmental costs which is our solar and investment compliance with environmental laws are recovered. As part of our rate case, it was determined that we have approximately $895 million of theoretical net depreciation surplus. FPL requested these we amortize the remaining lives of assets however the commission decided that we should amortize this amount to customers over the next four years.This will reduce depreciation expense by approximately $224 million per year over that period. Under our previous rate agreement, we had been reducing depreciation expense by roughly $125 million per year. Along with other changes in the depreciation parameters, we expect these depreciation expense in 2010 to be $30 million to $45 million lower than in 2009.The commission decided against a subsequent year revenue adjustment for 2011 and voted against the extension of the GBRA mechanism which will allow us to adjust based base rates for the first year revenue requirements of West County 3 upon its expected completion this summer of 2011. In summary, the decisions resulted in revenue requirement attributable to base rates of $75 million on an annualized basis.As such, we expect cash from operations in 2010 to be slightly higher than 2009 excluding the effects of the fuel clause. As Lew mentioned, there are many questions need to address for the business on a go forward basis. We are in the process of doing that and expect to further communicate our plans before the end of the second quarter.Let me now turn to NextEra Energy Resources where adjusted earnings per share were higher by approximately 6% for the full year driven by new wind additions and strong growth in our Wholesale, Marketing and Trading business. Those earnings however, were tempered by the extended outage at Seabrook Station, poor wind resource across our wind fleet and an unfavorable market conditions at our Texas fossil fuel facilities. They finished 2009 at approximately 1170 megawatts of wind facilities. During the fourth quarter, we close in our acquisition of 185 megawatts of recently completed wind projects from Babcock & Brown for approximately $352 million. For 2010, we are well hedged against the impacts of natural gas price movements and very significantly hedged against other price movements including spark spreads. Roughly 96% of equivalent gross margin we expect our existing asset portfolio to generate in 2010 protected against commodity price volatility.For 2011, comparable figures about 92% regarding sensitivities, the earnings sensitivity to change the natural gas prices on our 2010 open positioned as modest.For every dollar per MMBTu change in gas prices, the annualized impact is approximately $0.01 per share on an adjusted earnings basis at FPL Group for 2011, the equivalent adjusted earnings sensitivity is approximately $0.04 per share. As we have highlighted to you in many occasions, significant portion of our gross margin and earnings are generated by assets under long-term contracts. The weighted average remaining contract life of our non-wind assets that are under long-term contracts is 15 years. The comparable figure for the contracted wind assets is 17 years. The remaining contract lives are weighted by the gross margin dollars expected over the remaining lives of the various contracts.For certain wind facilities, we were eligible for an elective to receive production tax credits or PTCs for the first 10 years of the wind facilities lines. They will begin to have an increasing amount of PG see expirations as we begin the ten-year anniversary of Assets Put in Service as we ramped up our wind development program. In 2010, we will have an approximately $11 million less in equivalent gross margin relative to 2009 due to PTC expirations.In 2011, and 2012, the comparable figures are $24 million and $60 million respectively. The appendix to this presentation contains both the typical information we provide to you regarding our hedging status as well as these new pieces of information.For the fourth quarter of 2009, NextEra Energy Resources GAAP earnings were $170 million or $0.43 per share compared with $255 million or $0.66 per share in the prior period results. Adjusted earnings for the same period, which exclude the effect of non-qualifying hedges in net OTTI, were $152 million compared to $218 million. The equivalent adjusted earnings per share contributions were $0.37 and $0.55, respectively.for the full year 2009, NextEra Energy Resources GAAP earnings were $849 million or $2.08 per share compared with $915 million or $2.27 per share in 2008. Adjusted earnings which exclude the effect of non-qualifying hedges and net OTTI, were $882 million compared to $821 million. The equivalent adjusted earnings per share contributions were $2.16 and $2.04 per share, respectively.NextEra Energy Resources fourth quarter adjusted EPS declined $0.18 from last year's comparable quarter, a disappointing result relative to our expectations. Although we realized strong contribution from our new assets, our retail business and our Wholesale, Marketing and Trading business, performance from our existing assets was hindered by several factors, including the planned and extended outages at the Seabrook nuclear facility and the four wind and resource across our fleet.New wind investments contributed $0.10 per share incrementally, approximately $0.08 per share of this $0.10 improvement can be attributed to our decision to elect convertible investment tax credits this on 815 megawatts of wind build. On its own, the outage at Seabrook we've renewed by $0.13 per share compared to prior year. $0.05 due to the planned refueling, which we did not have in the comparable quarter last year and $0.08 due to the outage being extended.Poor wind resource across all geographies reduced results by $0.07 this quarter and contributions from our Texas gas fired facilities fell $0.07 per share relative to a year ago. Due to the significant impact on our earnings, we wanted to provide some additional detail on the Seabrook outage that occurred during the quarter. In October, Seabrook was taken off-line for a planned refueling outage after completing a record 511 day run of uninterrupted service.One element of the outage involved the replacement of one low-pressure rotor and the steam turbine with a new more efficient router. As the unit was ramping up, the full power in November 14, a higher-than-expected vibration level was detected in the steam turbine and units electricity output was reduced to 65% to minimize the vibration to allow for careful analysis of the problem. On December 6, the plant was taken off-line to implement the appropriate corrective measures and it was returned to service on December 24. The plant continues to operate today at full output and all indicators are within normal ranges. Safety is always our highest priority and at no time that the vibration level compromised nuclear safety.The wind resource in the fourth quarter was well below normal impacting the existing assets results by roughly $0.07 per share as compared to the year ago period. For the year, the full wind resource has reduced per share result relative to the prior year by approximately $0.15.Wholesale marketing and trading activities increased by $0.09 per share as market conditions were beneficial to this business. As we've indicated before, quarterly results from this segment will often be higher or lower than we expect based on a number of factors including market volatility and opportunities. All other factors that at a loss of $0.04 per share. Of this once it is attributable to higher interest expense, corporate G&A and taxes of 1 cent and share dilution and rounding of 1 cent each.for the full year 2009, adjusted earnings per share grew over 6% driven by new wind additions strong growth in our retail and wholesale power market in trading business, offset by the per wind resource, the outage at Seabrook and adverse market conditions across our market merchant fleet. New wind additions contributed $0.42 which includes $0.22 on our election to receive tax credits on 815 megawatts.From a cash perspective, this convertible investment tax credits totaled $470 million of which we have already received $100 million in cash in 2009 and expect to receive the balance in the first quarter of 2010.For the full year, the contribution from existing wind assets declined $0.19 most of which was due to the poor wind resource. Remembering that we manage our Texas business as a portfolio, our Texas merchant gas facilities were negatively impacted by $0.20 compared to the prior year due to poor market conditions while our Retail Supply business was up $0.10 due to lower energy supply costs.Approximately 90% of Retail Energy business' gross margin is generated in taxes. Remember that fore purposes of this light, retail business is part of existing asset.for the year, the merchant Northeast asset were down $0.03 due largely to unfavorable market conditions for the gas and Hydro assets and the outages at Seabrook in the fourth quarter offset partially by the lack of a refueling outage at Seabrook in the first quarter and favorable pricing at Seabrook. Wholesale marketing and trading contributed an additional $0.19. We will provide some additional color on the breakdown of all of our supply related and non-asset based businesses later in my remarks. The other category includes the impact of higher interest expense, corporate G&A, rounding differences and share dilution.As we anticipated in our third quarter conference call, the wind resource was particularly poor during the fourth quarter and indeed this entire year. To put it into perspective, based on actual wind speed observations, and public meteorological towers near our projects, this quarter was the worst quarter and this year, the worst year over the last 30 years. On the slide , we show both the fourth quarter and full year 2009 average historical wind speeds from 34 meteorological towers we believe are most geographically relevant to our various wind facilities.The raw data used to build this index is publicly available via Noah's website for a nominal annual fee. We wait these by our estimates of the long-term estimate megawatt production took for the portfolio. This wind speed index is intended to reflect the most basic components of the wind resource break it simply an indication of how fast the wind was blowing at a meteorological Mac measurement towers at specific points in time. This index is different from the wind energy index that we have shown in the past and that year, we have not made any adjustments to the data such as incorporating adjustments for the higher turbine height and running this adjusted wind speeds to turbine specific our curbs.Before you attempt the model of the wind resource yourselves, we would like to caution you that while we believe the wind speed at this towers can give you a good general sense of the wind resource, they do not give you the entire picture of what drives our wind fleet performance. The bottom 2 graphs of the slide show you the reason the wind speed index and the actual wind performance of our wind projects in Texas and the Midwest. These wind speed in this as our 93 and 75% correlated for our actual wind performance in Texas and the Midwest, respectively over the last two years.The aspects of the wind resource that are not captured by the simple measure of wind speed at the public towers include the fact the fact that the government on towers are generally 10 miles of 50 miles from our wind facilities. The towers are often at 10 meters whereas our wind turbines are primarily at 50 meters or 80 meters and data are typically hourly average measurements that do not reflect the actual distribution of wind speeds over time.However, we thought it was important to give you an unbiased view of the wind resource from towers that we do not own or manage.On the third quarter call, we indicated to you that we believe there is a correlation between El Ni√±o weather patterns and poor wind resource particularly across Texas and the Midwest were many of our wind investments are located. The El Ni√±o effect was particularly strong during the fourth quarter and we believe this event explains some of the poor wind resource that we experienced.The U.S. Natural Weather Services Climate Prediction Center is forecasting that El Ni√±o has reached its peak and will continue to be in effect into the second quarter. Although the El Ni√±o weather pattern is as stated to moderate over time, it strengthens duration has been difficult to predict.To be clear though, it is not possible for us to say how much the El Ni√±o pattern directly affects wind results although we can see evidence of its effect. Looking back, we can tell you that approximately 40% of the days in which the wind resource was poor during the fourth quarter, the dominant weather pattern across Texas and the Midwest regions was consistent with the El Ni√±o.For forecasting purposes, we assume we will experience normal weather. As I noted at the beginning of my remarks, weather can have a positive or negative impact to the individual components of our business that I noted that across the portfolio, the various impacts may offset one another. for your reference, we estimate that based on the wind turbines we have in service as of December 31, 2009, each 1% change in annual production equates to approximately $0.02 impact to our adjusted earnings at FPL Group.During 2009, I indicated that we would be providing further details on the relative contributions from both our supply related businesses and our non-asset based businesses. As we have noted to you in the past, our supply related businesses include our full requirements in retail supply business. Our non-asset based category includes power and gas marketing and trading operations.Also as we noted in the first quarter, our expectations has been that we plan to grow these businesses generally in line with the gross margin growth of the rest of NextEra Energy Resources and then in aggregate, they have represented approximately 5% to 8% of the total gross margin of NextEra Energy Resources since late 2006, which is when we first started presenting the gross margin information in this fashion. We indicated to you in the third quarter that the businesses were growing a bit more this year due to the favorable market conditions. Today, we would like to provide some detail on the performance of both the supply related and non-asset based businesses on a gross margin basis.For the full year 2009, full requirements contributed $74 million and our retail operations contributed $132 million in gross margin. Remember that the full requirements in retail operations serve in part as a hedge of our assets. In 2009, we hedged approximately 3.2 million-megawatt hours, a full requirement in retail load with energy and/or basis from our portfolio of merchant-generation assets. Additionally, as I mentioned earlier in my comments, the results of our Texas portfolio are an example of the benefits of having these complementary businesses. During 2009, the prevailing market conditions have reduced the earnings contribution from our merchant, Texas Gas Asset, benefited our Texas Retail Supply business.Power and gas, marketing and trading contributed $205 million in gross margin. None of these gross margin numbers include G&A, interest or other corporate charges that these businesses need to operate. And the inclusion of these discharges would of course temper the results of these businesses to an extent. We wanted to give you a view based on gross margin information since that is what we have previously provided. We have also provided the comparable gross margin contribution for the businesses for 2008. You will notice on the 2010 and 2011 slides located in the appendix of this presentation, that we have included gross margin detail for both the supply related and Non-Asset Based businesses. Providing further details on these businesses will be something that we plan to continue to work on during 2010.To summarize 2009, fourth quarter results on an adjusted basis, FPL contributed $0.45, NextEra Energy Resources contributed $0.37 and Corporate and Other was negative $0.03 contribution. As a total, $0.79 per share compared to $0.90 per share into 2008 fourth quarter or a 12% decrease year-over-year. On an adjusted basis for the full year 2009, FPL contributed $2.04, NextEra Energy Resources contributed $2.16 and Corporate and Other was a negative $0.15 contribution. As a total, $4.05 per share compared to $3.84 per share in 2008 or 5% increase year-over-year.For 2010, we believe that adjusted EPS expectations within the range of $4.25 and $4.65 are reasonable expectations. We are not providing earnings expectations beyond 2010 at this point, although we are currently planning on providing longer-term earnings expectations at our investor meeting in May.During the 2009 second quarter call, I mentioned that we were starting to see a slowdown in counterparties willingness to contract for long-term wind power. At the same time, we reduced wind build expectations for 2009 and the next several years. In addition, during the third quarter, I indicated that we have seen some pick up in activity in signing wind PPAs for our developed projects. I think it is fair to say that we had a very successful year, negotiating and signing wind purchase power agreements. Signing over 750 megawatts of long-term power purchase agreements during 2009, with an additional 300 to 400 of 2009 megawatts in advanced stages of negotiation. That said, the goal of adding a minimum of 1,000 megawatts of new wind with power purchase agreements over each of the next several years is not a slam dunk. The combination of lower power prices, primarily as a result of the economic downturn coupled with continued uncertainty regarding federal climate or renewable portfolio standards, is clearly adding to the industry's development challenges. We continue to see increased activity in the market for wind properties owned by distressed sellers when compared to six to nine months ago. We continue to be active on this front and are looking at a number of assets that we believe would fit nicely into our portfolio.  Although there's no assurance that any assets will be acquired, we are looking at several opportunities that will supplement the 1,000 megawatts of wind that we are expecting to add this year. As I have indicated before, we will have more to say about our long-term development plans for wind and other activities at our investor conference in May.Let me spend just a couple of minutes discussing our capital structure. Earlier this month, as a result of the FPL rate case, the three debt rating agencies placed the debt of both FPL and FPL Group capital on negative watch, signaling their intent to review the credit of the companies within the next 60 to 90 days. We have previously indicated to you, to both debt and equity investors, that we believe the strong capital position was important to our business model and we continue to believe that today. Over the last year or so, we have issued common stock through our aftermarket program totaling $160 million and plan to issue another $240 million to that same program this year subject to marketing conditions we view as acceptable. This would fulfill our goal of issuing $400 million of equity through this program in 2009 and 2010. This of course is not taking into account the ongoing issuances of common stock associated with our dividend reinvestment and employee programs which had roughly $40 million a year of issuances to those numbers.Also during 2009, we entered into a contract issue $350 million in equity in 2012, although essentially locking in the price of that issuance in 2009. We certainly understand that the outcome of the Florida rate case has caused some anxiety regarding the Florida regulatory and political environment. We cannot predict how soon this environment will improve. We also cannot predict what future actions each of the credit rating agencies will take on our debt ratings. However, our current and expected overall credit metrics remains strong. Additionally, we believe maintaining a strong balance sheet is in the long-term interest of our investors and our customers. We also believe that we can sustain our strong capital position while continuing to prudently invest in appealing opportunities that provide attractive returns to our shareholders. With that, let me now turn the call back over to Lew for some concluding remarks.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Armando. Even though we faced some unexpected challenges in 2009, we had a solid year overall, which is a testament to the strategy we've adopted at FPL Group. On a one-year basis, we delivered a total return to our shareholders of 9%, which lagge
componenttext: Thanks, Armando. Even though we faced some unexpected challenges in 2009, we had a solid year overall, which is a testament to the strategy we've adopted at FPL Group. On a one-year basis, we delivered a total return to our shareholders of 9%, which lagged the 26% return by the S&P 500 Index, but exceeded the 3% return by the S&P Electric Utilities Index.Over the longer term, shareholders have been handsomely rewarded by FPL Group strategy. In the past five years, our 66% return easily outpaced the 37% return for the Electric Utilities Index, and the 2% return of the S&P 500. And over the 10 years, our 253% return towered over the 134% return by the Electric Utilities Index and the negative 9% return by the S&P 500. We're proud of the returns we have delivered to you over the past 10 years. And you have our commitment that we will work hard to make the next 10 years just as rewarding. What is consistent across both of our main businesses is a strong commitment to operational excellence, financial strength, financial discipline and being a leading player in building the leading clean energy company of the future. The focus on these areas has served us well in the past, and I'm confident it will do so as well in the future. Let me close by extending a special thanks to the 15,000 employees of FPL Group who made 2009 a solid year. I've never worked with a more talented and committed team. And with that, I'll turn the call over to the conference moderator for questions. Thank you.

componenttext: I don't know if I'm ahead of the May Analyst Day to much, kind of given the challenges of the Florida economy seem to be the impediment in the rate case outcome. Do you guys think you file a rate case before you start to see real visible signs if the Florida economy is getting better by way of housing and unemployment before putting the case up again?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010

componenttext: Dan, Lew addressed that in the opening remarks, I think his quote was it's been 25 year since our last rate case, and it certainly won't be another 25 years until our next one. But that is getting a little bit ahead of really of our planning at this point. We spent a lot of time in the last couple of weeks really digesting the decisions that were reached by the commission. And also trying to understand what our plans should be for this year and for next year. But I think any comments from us at this point that to would target any specific rate case filing or any specific factors that we would like to see before we make a filing, I think it's just too early.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just turn to wind then. As you look at 2010 and some of the difficulties in more challenging environment, signed PPAs, with the convertible ITC out there, how much wind do you need under contract of 1,000 megawatts to move forward relative to build
componenttext: Let me just turn to wind then. As you look at 2010 and some of the difficulties in more challenging environment, signed PPAs, with the convertible ITC out there, how much wind do you need under contract of 1,000 megawatts to move forward relative to building kind of merchant or spot win for this year? And how will that affect your thought process for '11 and '12 as you try and get in queue for convertible ITCs after the 2010 expiration date?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's probably on purpose if I had three or four questions in there and just a couple of sentences. Let me try to address them. First, I'd say it's more subjective rather than objective when we make a determination of how much visibility we need and
componenttext: Yes, that's probably on purpose if I had three or four questions in there and just a couple of sentences. Let me try to address them. First, I'd say it's more subjective rather than objective when we make a determination of how much visibility we need and to power purchase agreements for the year before we decide to move forward. But we clearly, even today, we have pretty good visibility into the types of power purchase contracts and the terms of those power purchase contracts that we can sign in 2010. That's one of the things that we look at before we sit here in front of you and say that we still feel comfortable with the roughly 1,000 megawatts of wind in 2010. That could change. Clearly, it could change. But we feel comfortable based on the number of projects that we have and the visibility that we have into PPAs. And you also inserted convertible ITC in that. I did go into some detail either last quarter or the quarter before as to how we look at convertible ITCs. It's not 10 projects, each of 100 megawatts that we have on the list and say these are absolutely the 10 projects that we're going to build and because it's only these 10, we have a pretty good indication of which ones we're going to take convertible ITC on because obviously, you have the wind resource information, you've run the economics and so on. Projects shift, if ever so slightly, and ones that you believe at the beginning of the year that you had good visibility to build this year may actually fall off the list for a number of factors. But right now, our plan for 2010 is to take the convertible ITC on essentially 800, I was thinking of another list, on approximately 800 of the 1,000 megawatts that we think we would build. For 2011 and 2012, the rules, as we understand them, and we certainly have had plenty of discussions with others that are in a better position to understand them than us, either ones that write them, we believe that we will have projects that are in construction at the end of 2010 that we'll get built in 2011 and 2012. It's a little early for us to say at this point how many of those projects we believe will qualify for convertible investment tax credit. But we believe it's going to be more than a small amount.

componenttext: I might add though that the net effect of all of that is very much a function of what happens with legislation. We have legislation extending PTCs, but not including the equivalent of the convertible ITC. The pattern looks one way, but if it's the opposite of that or we continue to have the CITC, it looks very different. So a lot of it is a function of what happens in Congress.

componenttext: And then Secondly, on the Non-Asset Based businesses, I appreciate the additional disclosure there. headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, there obviously certainly is, and you'd expect us to know that. We looked at a couple of ways to show this information, Steve. And one of the ways that we could have shown the information would have been on an EBIT or EBITDA basis, certainly on
componenttext: Certainly, there obviously certainly is, and you'd expect us to know that. We looked at a couple of ways to show this information, Steve. And one of the ways that we could have shown the information would have been on an EBIT or EBITDA basis, certainly on an earnings basis. I actually felt uncomfortable with making a change to gross margin information that we have issued, that you had seen in the past. So I wanted to be somewhat consistent. I didn't want anyone to believe that we were kind of shifting the information because we wanted to highlight something differently. So that's why we presented it on a gross margin basis. The issue with presenting it on an earnings or EBIT basis at this point is we really haven't presented the rest of the portfolio for quite some time on an EBIT or EBITDA basis. And I don't want to start presenting part of the portfolio on an EBIT or EBITDA basis, and part of the portfolio on a gross margin basis. It is, as I indicated, one of the goals for this year is to provide a little more transparency on the things that you and others have asked for. We may eventually get there this year to providing more of a net number for these businesses. But for right now, we thought the appropriate step would be just to give our investors and analysts details of what we have previously provided. I certainly didn't want to be accused of providing different information that couldn't be reconciled to the past.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us a feeling for the commitment, I guess, for lack of a better word to the non-regulated credit rating. I mean, it disappeared [ph]  to a lot of your competitors on a non-regulated size. But on the other hand, I'm just wo
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us a feeling for the commitment, I guess, for lack of a better word to the non-regulated credit rating. I mean, it disappeared [ph]  to a lot of your competitors on a non-regulated size. But on the other hand, I'm just wondering how you look at it strategically going forward here, given what Moody's has said recently?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll make a couple of points there. You're right, it is different than what some people believe our competitors are. But as I've tried to indicate over and over again to both equity and debt investors, it's really a different business from most fo
componenttext: I guess I'll make a couple of points there. You're right, it is different than what some people believe our competitors are. But as I've tried to indicate over and over again to both equity and debt investors, it's really a different business from most folks that are out there, whoever might be on that competitor list. And NextEra Energy Resources has a business that is largely contracted for several years out with long-term contracts, with investment-grade counterparties. And it's also a business that we're growing, but we indicated that we would continue to grow that business prudently. We would continue to grow that business when we felt comfortable that the revenue stream i.e. the PPA or other mechanism we felt comfortable with. We were not going to be building merchant assets, and we haven't built merchant assets. I just want to clarify that first because I want to make sure that when we get lumped with others, that we all sit back and recognize that it really is a truly unique business. On what I thought was your primary point, how important is that to us and to the business,  Lew mentioned it, I mentioned it a couple of times, sitting here reading the script again, I almost thought to myself the third time I said it that, "Gee whiz, maybe we said it too much." But a strong financial position at both companies, we believe is in the long-term interest of our investors. Having said that, if you look at the credit metrics that we have, compared to others in the industry, our credit metrics in and of themselves are very strong. And it's something that we have focused on for a very long period of time. Certainly, even before I was here. Our credit metrics are improving year-over-year. And as I also indicated last year, if we were to go ahead with our plans for the next four to five years, that would mean some equity issuances in the future. We did that last year with our equity at the aftermarket program. I indicated just a couple of minutes ago that we were going to continue the aftermarket program this year to the tune of about $240 million. So I don't want anybody to think that it's not important to us, it clearly is important to us. But we're already a pretty strong company and we're truly unique.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm just wondering though with Moody's statement about a multi-notch downgrade at the non-reg, whether or not we might step up that equity other than the $240 million that you're mentioning. Do you think you might bring some of that forward or do you
componenttext: Yes, I'm just wondering though with Moody's statement about a multi-notch downgrade at the non-reg, whether or not we might step up that equity other than the $240 million that you're mentioning. Do you think you might bring some of that forward or do you feel that your credit metrics is strong enough as it is in your position within the industry is strong enough as it is that, that really isn't warranted even if you do have to get a multi-notch downgrade?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I read the Moody's information, what clearly comes across to me is their concern over the Florida regulatory environment. That is clear among the three rating agencies that, that was the driver for the actions that they've all taken. Now Moody's goes
componenttext: When I read the Moody's information, what clearly comes across to me is their concern over the Florida regulatory environment. That is clear among the three rating agencies that, that was the driver for the actions that they've all taken. Now Moody's goes an additional step, and indicates whether if there is a downgrade whether in fact the unregulated side, whether you have to bring down that a notch from the FPL Group or the holding company side and the Florida Power & Light Company side. I can't predict exactly what Moody's is going to do. But I also want to make clear that our credit rating is important to us and we've spoken to all the agencies, but none of the agencies that I know of have indicated that we have a problem with our metrics. And when you're talking about additional equity, when you're talking about other changes to your capital structure, you're generally talking about those situations where you really need to improve your metrics, and we may. But that's not the primary point of either Moody's write-up or the other two agencies' write-up.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: GEXA had a great year this past year. And one of the reasons it had a great year was because it didn't have to actually pay a lot of ancillary fees to generators like Lamar and Forney. So Lamar and Forney didn't have a very good year and GEXA really had a
componenttext: GEXA had a great year this past year. And one of the reasons it had a great year was because it didn't have to actually pay a lot of ancillary fees to generators like Lamar and Forney. So Lamar and Forney didn't have a very good year and GEXA really had a decent year. So our expectations for next year is that we'll balance that a little more.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we will go to Hugh Wynne, Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And we will go to Hugh Wynne, Sanford Bernstein.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that you guys are considering your options on the regulatory front. And therefore, I'm not in a position to talk about regulatory strategy. I was wondering if you might add a little bit of color on the factors that are being weighed in that d
componenttext: I appreciate that you guys are considering your options on the regulatory front. And therefore, I'm not in a position to talk about regulatory strategy. I was wondering if you might add a little bit of color on the factors that are being weighed in that decision-making process. In particular, I'm a little surprised at your caution.That Would seem to me that if you just come out of a decision where you end up with the lowest rates in the state, the lowest ROE in the state, that the Commission has denied recovery of major investments, they will be coming online this year, that it's difficult to see the downside to filing again. How could a new rate case make things worse? And on the other hand, the prospect of continuing to invest in the unavoidable expansion of corporate base without relief seems a fairly dreary prospect. So could you talk a little bit about what's going into the decision-making process regarding your regulatory strategy?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We can say little. Look, those are all good questions and great observations, and those are the things that we're talking about right now. But it's a little early for us to come out this week and say that we have a three-step plan and these are the plans,
componenttext: We can say little. Look, those are all good questions and great observations, and those are the things that we're talking about right now. But it's a little early for us to come out this week and say that we have a three-step plan and these are the plans, and we're going to file a rate case in the next month. I think everybody kind of understand, and maybe not everyone is going out and saying exactly what you're seeing, but everybody understands that we've got some significant decisions that we need to make. Lew expressed clearly a disappointment in the outcome, including not getting any revenue requirements for West County 3 in 2011. But even today, our rate case isn't completely done. I mean, rates have to be set later on in the week. And it's just too early for us to give you and the rest of our investors those answers. We're working on them, we believe that by the end of the second quarter, we will be able to come out with a package of answers and strategy that makes sense, and that we would have the support of investors. But for us to say anything else at this point is really premature.

componenttext: Can you provide any like guidance as to the likely or the expected level of megawatt-hour sales of Florida Power & Light in 2010 given what you saw in the fourth quarter and from the first month of this year?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hugh, I'm not going to add much probably that's going to help you with this. But as Armando said, the proceedings aren't even over yet. We haven't even seen a written order. There's a lot of variables. I think earlier in the call, somebody mentioned the e
componenttext: Hugh, I'm not going to add much probably that's going to help you with this. But as Armando said, the proceedings aren't even over yet. We haven't even seen a written order. There's a lot of variables. I think earlier in the call, somebody mentioned the economy. Clearly, that's a factor. I mentioned in my comments that a comment by one of the Commissioners, but another comment by one of the Commissioners was, "Well you can always come back with a limited scope hearing. You have to understand really the pros and cons of a limited scope versus a full-fledged rate case." We are in the midst of really reassessing our investments like I mentioned to you before. So that definitely plays into things, and then it's not lost on us that this is an election year and so it's anything more than that. But there's a whole host of variables that have to get baked into this. But as I said, we sure aren't going to be taking another 25 years to put forth a full-fledged rate case. So just stay tuned, we'll get answers for all of you on this very important question as soon as we possibly can.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we will take our final question from Edward Heyn with Catapult.
componenttext: And we will take our final question from Edward Heyn with Catapult.

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just talk to you briefly about the treatment from the Florida Public Utility Commission, I think there's been a lot of concern over the last couple of months. And while that concern seems warranted, it appears to be much due about nothing, the
componenttext: I wanted to just talk to you briefly about the treatment from the Florida Public Utility Commission, I think there's been a lot of concern over the last couple of months. And while that concern seems warranted, it appears to be much due about nothing, there's little impact to your financial profitability. You only trend to your guidance by about $0.20, and you also insinuated that you may not even be going in for rate case very soon. Can you kind of talk about what the driver to this financial resilience is, is it cost cutting? Is your growth forecast coming up? Is there something else that's offsetting kind of, I guess, negative rate order relative to your expectations?

headline: FPL Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm glad that you've got some positive comments. I don't know that it's much to do about nothing. When we say we're disappointed in the outcome, we are. When we first gave guidance last year over in the fourth quarter on 2010, we gave a fairly wide range
componenttext: I'm glad that you've got some positive comments. I don't know that it's much to do about nothing. When we say we're disappointed in the outcome, we are. When we first gave guidance last year over in the fourth quarter on 2010, we gave a fairly wide range to that guidance. And so we're bringing down the top by $0.20. I can't talk about our plans for O&M at this point. Those are preliminary, they're not finalized. But I'd say that the continued growth of NextEra certainly is helping us from 2009 and from 2010. I'd also say that, as Lew mentioned and as I showed in the FPL breakdown of earnings, the revenue adjustments that we got on West County 1 and West County 2 in 2009 are certainly helpful. And then there's other revenue outside of retail rates, this was a retail rate case in Florida that are helpful to the Florida Power & Light story. So overall, I don't know whether it's much to do about nothing. I mean, it's a huge disappointment on the FPL side. But last quarter, at this time, or late October when we were telling you what we thought our 2010 range was, I think we did a pretty decent job of looking out into the future and trying to predict what different outcomes were or would be.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, to some extent, we had. I think it would behoove us to understand all of the ranges. Having said that, there are other positive factors that have happened since then that we weren't looking at back at the end of the third quarter. FPL did have in the first month of this year already some pretty favorable weather. So all things have to kind of balance themselves out. But I don't know if I could say anything else than that, Ted.
