headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, there's a couple of ways to actually qualify for CITC in '11 and '12, right? One of them is a Safe Harbor provision in the rules and the other one is actually the start of construction. We're going to use both of those to qualify a majority of our pr
componenttext: Dan, there's a couple of ways to actually qualify for CITC in '11 and '12, right? One of them is a Safe Harbor provision in the rules and the other one is actually the start of construction. We're going to use both of those to qualify a majority of our projects wind and solar projects in '11 and '12 and for solar, actually in '13 and 14. We've talked about the Genesis project, obviously, there are others that we have in our pipeline that we have not discussed. And that's something that we pay a lot of attention to. As you can imagine, it's the leader in the industry. We have access to and have been able to have discussions with a lot of folks that are writing these rules. So at this point, we feel fairly comfortable that a significant portion of our development plans in '11 and '12 for wind, and '13 and '14 for solar will qualify for CITC.

componenttext: I mean, it'd be fair to assume anything that you think is fair, but we're not going to comment on what we believe the ROE would be. We may in the future, but clearly at the settlement agreement is approved, we would be required to stay within the 9% to 11%. If we're under and this is in the agreement, if we're under the 11%, we would have to use amortization as a depreciation credit to get us up, that doesn't necessarily mean that we have to get to 11%. If we are over 11%, we would not be able to use any depreciation credit to keep us over 11%. And let me just kind of go back on something I just said because the last part of it, I misspoke on the first part. Under 9% were required to amortization credit to get us up to 9%. And we're over 11%. We can't use any to keep us over 11%.

componenttextpreview: No, I was trying to answer another question and I thought Dan was trying to get to. I think a presumption by investors and analysts, the midpoint of 10% was in our previous guidance I think is appropriate. You're trying to link that previous guidance in,
componenttext: No, I was trying to answer another question and I thought Dan was trying to get to. I think a presumption by investors and analysts, the midpoint of 10% was in our previous guidance I think is appropriate. You're trying to link that previous guidance in, i.e. at 10% and also 2011 earnings. Let me kind of explained it this way and maybe it will be helpful to you and others on the call. The amount of gross margin reduction for what I'll call the lower build in 2011 for both wind and solar is roughly $0.10 and you can the take the gross margin number, you can tax affect it, it's roughly $0.10 and again that'd be a reduction. The reduction in the lower commodity prices from either or on contract wind assets and it's slightly extending the term of the merchant time that those projects will be in a merchant state is roughly $0.07. The reduction in trading power and gas trading proprietary power and gas trading that I mentioned in 2011 is also $0.07. In this call, I also said that the amount of fuel savings attributable to West County 3 are roughly in line with but slightly less than the revenue requirements, which is roughly a revenue requirements are roughly $100 million. If you add all that together, and again, I'm going just from the revenue line, I'm not really focused on the bottom end, but if you add all that together, you'll roughly to get a net $0.10 deduction from whatever midpoint you started with. If you add all that together, what we've actually done is we brought the midpoint down of our 2011 guidance down $0.05 from $4.45 to $4.40. That's the way I look at it.

componenttext: I think that is the question, Greg, asked. I think the assumption of using 10% is a reasonable assumption, what I was trying to point out, Greg, is that the range is -- to Dan, that the range is 9% to 11% and if we get under 9%, we'd be required to use amortization to get up to 9%. Now in my comments today, I also indicated that we had not taken any depreciation credit year to date for 2010. And we can use a total of $776 million during the three year period of the pending settlement agreement. So I don't think I have to connect the dots necessarily, but that should give everyone an indication of where the ROE range would be and would be a little smaller than 9% to 11% for 2011.

componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Lew. I just wanted to comment about the uncertainty on wind and Armando said that it's clearly a tougher market right now than what we might have experienced a few years ago, but I want to point out that even in the sloppiest times of the w
componenttext: Steve, this is Lew. I just wanted to comment about the uncertainty on wind and Armando said that it's clearly a tougher market right now than what we might have experienced a few years ago, but I want to point out that even in the sloppiest times of the wind market, we didn't have 250 megawatts of PPAs as of the end of the third quarter that when we're walking out of the next year. So some of you who are as familiar with the wind development business, I mean a lot of times we would have a lot of things in the works but we didn't have deals signed up at that point. And so I would not -- I want to make sure nobody's looking at what we just reported as being a big negative. It's a tough market out there, but we gave you our estimate as to what we're seeing and I think you could argue there's more variability about it then maybe what was happening in the frostiest markets. But we have a fair amount of visibility in the floor, I wouldn't discount the guidance we just gave you.

componenttext: No. There's two numbers, right? There's currently constructed and on contracted as roughly 350 megawatts. It's a little less than that. The last time I'd mentioned that number, it was 400 megawatts. The amount that we would expect to have at the end of the year i.e. because you're referring to 680 megawatts, some of those 680 megawatts do not have current contracts. So unless and it could, but unless something -- unless we get a contract by the end of the year on some of those projects, at the end of the year, we'll roughly have 700 megawatts of on contracted wind plants that had been constructed. And that's different just kind of add to that, we have roughly 1700 megawatts of on contracted, but hedged the wind projects out in Texas. Now when we built those, those weren't ever expected to be contracted. So the 700 that I'm talking about for the end of the year are those that we do expect to get contracts on, but we do not have contracts on or we do not expect to have contracts on at the end of the year. And I noticed you changed the presentation this quarter to look at -- to the trailing '12 customers rather than sequential quarter, but as we look back to June, and look back you only added maybe 3,000 customers in the third quarter, which is obviously slowed can you talk about that a little?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Historically, probably, or I don't know, towards the end of 2008 or 2009, before that time, we had always shown this customer growth chart the way you're seeing it now. We compared the average customers of this quarter to the average customers to the
componenttext: Yes. Historically, probably, or I don't know, towards the end of 2008 or 2009, before that time, we had always shown this customer growth chart the way you're seeing it now. We compared the average customers of this quarter to the average customers to the year ago quarter, we had always done that so when we got to the period of significant customer reductions or at least significant for us, we wanted to provide investors some additional information because it was almost -- it was less meaningful to look at what happened a year ago when we were getting significant changes every month. And so for the last probably 12 to 18 months or it might be a little shorter than that, we switched over to less just tell you what's happened with the sequential quarters. Now you might argue with us, I think we've got a little more stability now and because we have a little more stability now, and because we have a little more stability now and because we have a little more stability now, we've kind of gone back to what we were doing before, because I think it is a better comparison than just a sequential quarter and primarily because of the seasonality in the business. So that's why we've gone back to it. To answer your question, one of your questions, we have on a sequential basis about 3000 more customers at the end of September 2010 than we had a at June of 2010.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: It absolutely is the seasonality. If I go back to at least a rough number is not a year ago September on sequential basis, we had lost 2,000 customers in 2008 September again a sequential basis we had lost 11,000 customers in September of '07 but things w
componenttext: It absolutely is the seasonality. If I go back to at least a rough number is not a year ago September on sequential basis, we had lost 2,000 customers in 2008 September again a sequential basis we had lost 11,000 customers in September of '07 but things were still going pretty darn good and a sequential basis, we'd only added 10,000 customers. So I'm not necessarily disappointed by the 3000 customers. I'm pretty happy with the 27,000 quarter-to-quarter. We haven't seen that type of quarter-to quarter grow, 27,000, sense since the June '08 quarter.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I guess, I think about it just a little differently, Ted. This is a great deal for customers. And it provides them significant stability, financial stability all the way through the end of 2012 and it continues to allow us to put some assets that wil
componenttext: Well I guess, I think about it just a little differently, Ted. This is a great deal for customers. And it provides them significant stability, financial stability all the way through the end of 2012 and it continues to allow us to put some assets that will longer term saver customers a lot of money. In return for that, the settlement provides some financial stability for us during these times and potentially keep us from filing a new rate case during these times. So there's clearly some puts and takes in the agreement. Overall as I've said before and as Lew has said before, this is a positive both for our customers and for the company and it does provide both stability through 2012.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: The other thing I would add just for 2012 at the is you also have the full year impact of West County 3, not just the half year impact and you also have the benefit of both the operates as well as the PVC on Canapole [ph] and Riviera. So there are several growth drivers for utility in 2012 versus 2011.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Analyst Day, when you talked about the 5% to 7% growth rate through 14, it seemed like you are actually kind of say that, that was conservative and that if you did the math, you could potentially exceed that. With the adjustments that you've made t
componenttext: On the Analyst Day, when you talked about the 5% to 7% growth rate through 14, it seemed like you are actually kind of say that, that was conservative and that if you did the math, you could potentially exceed that. With the adjustments that you've made to the near term forecast, is that still valid or you now kind of feeling that the 5% is less conservative?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I didn't say conservative. I think the questions that were presented will JWAS, you've got  a growth rate of earnings that FPL of XY, you've got a growth rate of energy resources going from X to Y, and what I said was you've got also accounts for the
componenttext: Yes, I didn't say conservative. I think the questions that were presented will JWAS, you've got  a growth rate of earnings that FPL of XY, you've got a growth rate of energy resources going from X to Y, and what I said was you've got also accounts for the fact that we've got dilution, we got other expenses going into this. But I felt comfortable with the 5% to 7%. It was clearly towards the high end but I also said that there was a significant amount of execution to do that from 2010 to 2014 and that I was concerned with the state of the economy. What's happened since then is -- some of those things that kind of played themselves out. We're now talking about reduced build at least from what we had in our plan next year, although we're still in the range of 700 to 1000 megawatts of wind. So some of those things have kind of played out. Now is not the time for me to discuss whether we are at the top end or at the bottom end. We feel comfortable with the range that we provided and I'll repeat what I said back then that in this economy, there remains a significant amount of execution risks on part, but as I look at the details of the capital investments that we have to make both of the Florida Power & Light Company side and at the energy resources side, including transmission development in Texas, I feel pretty -- I feel like there's some pretty darn good opportunities for us to invest capital is a very attractive rates from now through 2014. And so I feel comfortable with a range but we shouldn't forget that they're still execution risk.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: This is Jim Robo, again. Let me just add that there have been several questions around 13 and 14 and I think it's important to remember and our just mentioned one of the drivers for '13 and '14 which is the transmission to $800 million of transmission investment in Texas. But we have $2.5 billion of solar investment that is about to become under construction with signed contracts that come online in '13 and '14. Those are significant earnings drivers for energy resources in the '13 and '14 period. And are reflected in anything you see in the 2011 and 2012 charts.

So all the matters that have been deferred have now been brought forward and put on that agenda and it would be a function of whether the district court of appeals has ruled by that date or not. If it doesn't rule by that date, there's several more dates left in the year and of course, commission could always opt to have a special agenda to get this approved. And we feel pretty good. There's a lot -- all the parties really are pretty actively supporting the agreement and asking the commission to vote on it as soon as possible.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then back to the other Armando, on the wind slide, you talked about construction cost coming down, just maybe give us a little clarity on that, how that plays into construction cost?
componenttext: And then back to the other Armando, on the wind slide, you talked about construction cost coming down, just maybe give us a little clarity on that, how that plays into construction cost?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've seen really since 2008, we've seen construction cost in this industry come down. I would continue to say as I've said before that there is more downward pressure on cost than there is upward pressure. Here over, I'd say the last six to nine mo
componenttext: Well, we've seen really since 2008, we've seen construction cost in this industry come down. I would continue to say as I've said before that there is more downward pressure on cost than there is upward pressure. Here over, I'd say the last six to nine months, I've seen some pretty significant decreases. There is still differences as we've mentioned before in different regions of the country that the West particularly the California region is generally more expensive than the Midwest or some other areas that we're building. But if we were to put together the same kind of example that we put together for investors before, which is generally a Midwest type of example, I think the last time Midwest type of cash flow earnings example, I think the last time we put it together, the range, the KW range is somewhere between 1800 and 2000. If I were to put that together now, the range would probably be 1600 to 1800. So I mean, we are seeing cost decreases, and that's very helpful when you're dealing with the challenging environment because it allows you to protect the earnings that you expect from these investments.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last on the drilling program, just if you could give us a little better understanding of the decision process so you decided to go forward with the drilling. You hedged and then you decided not to go forward so then you unwound the hedges. So can you give
componenttext: Last on the drilling program, just if you could give us a little better understanding of the decision process so you decided to go forward with the drilling. You hedged and then you decided not to go forward so then you unwound the hedges. So can you give us a little understanding into what happened there and what caused you after deciding to go forward and not to decide to go forward?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the quarterly basis, we go through and we take a look at that business just like we do many of our other businesses. In this particular circumstance, we had hedged the wells or we had hedged the expected production from the wells. And as we looked at t
componenttext: On the quarterly basis, we go through and we take a look at that business just like we do many of our other businesses. In this particular circumstance, we had hedged the wells or we had hedged the expected production from the wells. And as we looked at the economics and then declining natural gas environment, we believe that it made more sense for us to take the capital that we had allocated to those wells and put it to use in other places and so that meant that we were able to flatten out the hedges and when we flattened out the hedges, at least internally, we take all of our documentation pretty seriously. These are non-qualifying hedges, which may not mean a whole heck of a lot to you, but sort of like internal hedge accounting and our documentation once we flattened out the hedges for these particular hedges required us to take the gain in this case. It would have required us to take the loss, so there was a loss, but it was a gain and we made the right economic decision and we moved on. This was a small -- it was $0.04 or so for the quarter but it was just the smallest subset of wells that we were dealing with. It's a business that we've continued to be very happy to be in and with the hedges that we have in place, we feel pretty good about the remaining investment that's not to say that in the future we may not change our mind on some of those. But it's a business that we've got heck of a lot of knowledge from as well as some pretty good returns on.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We should generally anticipate that when you decide to go forward over and to review it, it's a decision that you're going to go forward with. So we should, I do want to say $0.04 non-recurring, but we should not expect you're going to have the hedge gain
componenttext: We should generally anticipate that when you decide to go forward over and to review it, it's a decision that you're going to go forward with. So we should, I do want to say $0.04 non-recurring, but we should not expect you're going to have the hedge gains on a regular basis.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call.Lew Hay, NextEra Energy's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, will provide an overview of NextEra Energy's performance and recent accomplishments.
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call.
Lew Hay, NextEra Energy's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, will provide an overview of NextEra Energy's performance and recent accomplishments. Lew will be followed by Armando Pimentel, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the specifics of our financial results.
Also joining us this morning are Jim Robo, President and Chief Operating Officer of NextEra Energy; Armando Olivera, President and Chief Executive Officer of Florida Power & Light Company; and Mitch Davidson, President and Chief Executive Officer of NextEra Energy Resources, which we will refer to as Energy Resources in this presentation. Following our prepared remarks, our senior management team will be available to take your questions.
We will be making statements during this call that are forward looking. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ materially from our forward-looking statements.
If any of our key assumptions are incorrect or because of other factors discussed in today's earnings news release and the comments made during this conference call in the Risk Factors section of the accompanying presentation or in our latest reports and filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, each of which can be found in the Investors section of our website, www.nexteraenergy.com. We do not undertake any duty to update any forward-looking statements.
Please also note that today's presentation includes references to adjusted earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. You should refer to the information contained in the slides accompanying this presentation for definitional information and reconciliations of the non-GAAP measure to the closest GAAP financial measure.
With that, I will turn the call over to Lew Hay. Lew?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Rebecca, and good morning, everyone. NextEra Energy continued to deliver solid results in the third quarter of 2010, increasing adjusted earnings per share by more than 5% over the prior year quarter from $1.38 to $1.45.The most signifi
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Rebecca, and good morning, everyone. NextEra Energy continued to deliver solid results in the third quarter of 2010, increasing adjusted earnings per share by more than 5% over the prior year quarter from $1.38 to $1.45.
The most significant development during the quarter was the settlement agreement we reached with the principal parties involved in our rate case. We believe this agreement is in the best interest of all the parties involved, especially the approximately 8.7 million Floridians we serve. The FPL's typical residential customer bill is already the lowest of all 55 utilities in the state of Florida, and under the terms of this agreement which is awaiting approval by the Florida Public Service Commission, retail base rates would remain frozen through 2012. 
Armando Pimentel will discuss the elements of the agreement in greater detail. For my part, I want to thank those who represent Florida‚Äôs electric consumers for working with us the craft and agreement that should provide financial stability for customers and the company alike.
Our investment in Florida electrical infrastructure which this rate settlement will allow us to continue have provided significant benefits for our customers. Compared to the national average, our bills are 24% lower, our operating maintenance costs are 34% lower, our reliability is 46% higher and our fleet is cleaner, producing electricity with 35% fewer carbon dioxide emissions, 55% fewer sulfur dioxide emissions and 75% fewer nitrogen oxide emissions.
In other development with FPL, we continue to make progress on our third combined cycle unit at the West County Energy Center, which is expected to come online around the middle of 2011. When complete, the West County Energy Center will be one of the largest and cleanest fossil fuel facilities in the United States. In addition, we have begun construction activities at our Cape Canaveral plant, the modernized Canaveral and review of our beach facilities, which are scheduled to come online in 2013 and 2014, respectively, are designed to have a heat rate below 6,500 compared to a current industry average of more than 10,000. They're expected to be among the most efficient natural gas plants in the nation with significant customer benefits in terms of fuel and other savings. 
Environmentally, the new units are expected to be far cleaner than the units they replace, reducing the rate of sulfur dioxide emissions by 98%, the rate of nitrogen oxide emissions by 93% and the rate of particular emissions by 89%.
At energy resources, we have added approximately 1,260 megawatts of new wind capacities since the end of the second quarter of 2009 and expect that at year end 2010, we'll continue to be the nation's leader in wind energy generation. Looking ahead, while we clearly see some uncertainty in the renewables Development business, we continue to see profitable growth opportunities in both the Wind and Solar businesses. To that end, we are cautiously optimistic that in 2011, we will add approximately 700 to 1,000 megawatts of wind assets to the portfolio. 
Now also encouraging is the renewed interest we're seeing in differential membership transaction otherwise known as tax equity deals which had all but vanished during the recession. During the quarter we entered into an innovative transaction that will allow us to reduce the amount of production tax credits that we may have otherwise deferred on our balance sheet in the future.
On the solar front, our 250-megawatt Genesis solar project has now received the majority of the necessary permits and approvals, including all required approvals from the state of California. Genesis will be located in one of the best solar resource regions in the United States, and we will deploy the same proven solar trough technology at use in our St. Martin facilities. 
On the national policy front, I wish I could say that everyone in Washington shared our commitment to expanding the renewable energy industry. But as we have seen the summer and fall, the clean energy policy has been caught up by gridlock in Washington. As long as there's uncertainty hangs over the electric power industry, capital that would otherwise be usefully deployed will continue to sit on the sidelines. This will not only jeopardize nation's lead renewable energy technologies that we help plan here such as wind power, but it will cost the economy thousands of jobs at a time when we need them the most. Of course, even with the absence of new legislation, it appears that the Environmental Protection Agency will be putting  de facto price on carbons for the enforcement of regulations governing sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, mercury and coal ash. As time when analysts and others are predicting that the industry will retire tens of thousands of megawatt of coal-fired generation, NextEra Energy remains in the enviable position of producing only 4% of its power from coal.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Armando Pimentel.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lew, and good morning to everyone. I would like to share a couple of additional accomplishments before we get into the financial details of the quarter. During the quarter, we continue to execute well against our financing plan, issuing a mixtu
componenttext:
Thank you, Lew, and good morning to everyone. I would like to share a couple of additional accomplishments before we get into the financial details of the quarter. During the quarter, we continue to execute well against our financing plan, issuing a mixture of debt and equity securities from both international and domestic sources of capital. As Lew mentioned, during the quarter, we completed another differential membership transaction relating to 309 megawatts of wind energy projects in North Dakota and Iowa. This transaction represents a unique structure for energy resources in which the differential part membership investor makes an initial upfront payment that will make additional payments overtime tied to the energy production of the wind projects. This structure allows us to raise tax equity for existing projects that have been previously financed with project debt.
We continue to seek opportunities to minimize the growth of deferred production tax credits or PTCs on our balance sheet and the availability of this structure would allow us to receive compensation for future PTCs before we have otherwise been able to monetize them. We would consider using the structure again in the future. In September, we sold 20 year FPL Group capital senior notes with the principal amount of JPY  10 billion. At the same time, FPL Group capital entered into swaps that hedged against currency movements and fixed the interest-rate associated with the Notes. Net proceeds were USD $120 million. As we highlighted at the Investor Conference, we believe we're very well diversified in terms of primary markets and regions when it comes to raising debt. We will continue to see credit globally and execute those transactions that we consider to be most favorable. 
Also in September, we sold $402.5 million of equity units, which consist of a contract to purchase NextEra energy common stock in the future and an interest in five-year FPL Group capital debenture. We were pleased with the terms and note that this issuance is consistent with the equity plan we discussed with investors in May. And lastly, in October, we entered into approximately $750 million of forward-starting interest rates swaps designed to lock in rates for future debt issuances, which are expected to refinance scheduled maturities of FPL Group capital debentures in 2011 and 2013. Long-term interest rates are at historically low levels and we plan for these instruments to allow us to hedge a portion of our future debt re-financings.
Earlier this month, the Texas Public Utilities Commission granted our certificate of convenience and necessity or CCN for a 36-month portion of the CREZ transmission project awarded to our subsidiary Lone Star transmission. The CCN gives us assurance that we will get recovery on this portion of our investment and it clears the way for us to begin construction on this portion of the line. We requested that this section be evaluated separately in the expectation that it would allow us to expedite the process for this portion of the line. We are optimistic that we will get the CCN for the balance of the 300-mile project by the end of this year.
In the third quarter of 2010, NextEra energies GAAP net income was $720 million or $1.74 per share. NextEra Energy adjusted 2010 third quarter adjusted earnings and adjusted EPS were $602 million and $1.45 per share. The difference between the GAAP results and the adjusted results is the exclusion of the mark in our non-qualifying hedge category and the exclusion of net other than temporary impairments on certain investment or OTTI.
For the third quarter, Florida Power & Light reported net income of $308 million or $0.74 per share. Before we get into the details of the quarter, I would like to spend a couple of minutes on the rate case settlement agreement. As Lew mentioned, but it bears repeating, we strongly believe this agreement is positive for our customers and our investors alike. Under the terms of the agreement, retail-base rates would remain frozen as specified in the agreement through the end of 2012 and the authorized regulatory ROE or return on equity would remain at 10% plus or minus 100 basis points. FDL would be permitted to recover the base revenue requirements associated with West County Energy Center unit 3 through to capacity cost up to the amount of the projected fuel savings attributable to the unit. This mechanism allows for current cash recovery without an expected increase in the customers‚Äô total bill. 
We currently estimate that the 2011 fuel savings will be roughly in line with but slightly less than the revenue requirements for the plant based on current commodity prices and generation mix. The settlement would allow FPL the flexibility to vary the annual amortization of theoretical depreciation reserve surplus or depreciation credit to keep FPL's earned regulatory ROE within the approved range of 9% to 11% subject to certain annual and total caps.
The $267 million annual cap on the depreciation credit applies to each year of the agreement, but any unused amount in a given year to be carried forward and would be available for use in subsequent years. No more than $776 million of the depreciation credit could be taken during the term of the agreement. The agreement has a support of the Attorney General's office, the office of public counsel and the other principal parties in our rate case, as well as the recommended approval of the PFC staff. Given all of this, we believe approval is the most probable outcome and this forms the basis for our accounting for the quarter. As such, on a year-to-date basis, and as a result of favorable weather, we have not recorded any depreciation credit in order to be in compliance with the regulatory ROE provisions of the settlement agreement.
The table shown here summarizes the earnings drivers for Florida Power & Light for the just-completed quarter. In total, earnings decreased by $0.01 per share. The increase in base revenues related to West County Energy Center units 1 and 2, weather and the impact of our base rate increase were roughly offset by the increase in depreciation expense. Not only as a result of the addition of the West County units, but also due to the reduction of surplus depreciation amortization, which increases net depreciation expense consistent with the pending settlement agreement.
We are continuing to see some improvement as it relates to our customer metrics. The table in the upper left shows the change in retail kilowatt-hour sales versus last year's comparable period. Overall, retail kilowatt-hour sales grew by 3%, an improvement due primarily to higher weather-related usage but also from modest growth in customers. Non-weather-related or underlying usage growth mix and all other was essentially flat. As depicted in the graph in the upper right-hand corner, during the third quarter of 2010, we had approximately 27,000 more customers than we did in the comparable period of 2009. We continue to be cautiously optimistic that our customer growth is returning and we are encouraged that we continue to see modest increases in customer accounts.
The graph on the bottom left of the page shows inactive and low usage customers, which we believe depicts the level of empty homes in our service territory. Although inactive accounts are down relative to last year, they remained relatively flat as compared to the second quarter. Low usage accounts continue to decline during the third quarter. The chart on the bottom right depicts the level of new housing starts for single-family homes and FPL service territory. Housing starts are fairly good leading indicator of certain additions to our customer base roughly a year out. After experiencing rapid declines during the recession, the volume of housing starts appears to have stabilized. However, the current volume of permits remains low or about 12% of what it was at the height of the housing room that preceded the recession. 
We continue to see some improvements in many of our customer metrics, and for the longer-term, believe Florida will continue to be a very attractive destination to which people will move. In fact, just this month, Florida was selected as the second most popular state for which baby boomers would like to move according to our Harris Poll survey. However, in the short term, we remain cautious about the strength of the economy.
Let me now turn to energy resources. Since the end of the second quarter 2009, we have added approximately 1260 megawatts of new wind generation and continue to be the nation‚Äôs leading producer of wind of power. In addition, we have continued to make progress on our solar development pipeline. During the quarter, Genesis solar thermal project received approvals from the California Public Utilities Commission and the California Energy Commission. Genesis has also been selected by the Bureau of Land Management as a fast-track project, and we are hopeful that the project will receive BLM approval in the next couple of weeks. These approvals are major milestones in the development of this roughly $1 billion project, which we expect to be brought online in 2013 and 2014. This project has been many years in the making and we are very encouraged to see state and federal agencies working together to bring the benefits of these clean energy project for the citizens of California.
Energy resources reported third quarter 2010 GAAP earnings of $386 million or $0.93 per share. Adjusted earnings for the third quarter which exclude the effect of non-qualifying hedges and net OTTI were $267 million or $0.64 per share. As we mentioned in the first quarter, we have changed the methodology for allocating interest and shared costs to affiliates and this historical figures have been changed to reflect the change.
Energy resources third quarter adjusted EPS was up $0.05 relative to last year's comparable quarter. New wind investments contributed $0.05 per share, of this roughly $0.03 reflects our ability to recognize a state investment tax credit on some of our wind projects. As always, we will continue to seek opportunities for enhanced economics in states with incremental incentives. We continue to estimate that we will elect to take convertible investment tax credit or as we call them CITCs on approximately 600 megawatts of new wind generation to be placed in service in 2010. 
In aggregate, the existing portfolio contributed $0.05 relative to the prior year. Our existing wind assets contributed $0.04 driven primarily by a better wind resource. Performance from our existing merchant assets was down by $0.01 while contracted assets realized a $0.02 increase due to the commencement of long-term contracts on our markets hook 750 in blythe facilities.
During the third quarter, evaluation of our shale gas well drilling program. We determined that we would not move forward on a subset of future drilling opportunities whose output we had previously hedged. As we have previously communicated, upon approval of a well drilling program, we hedge the anticipated production from those wells in order to lock in a substantial amount of the wells economics. Our decision to not proceed on these specific wells resulted in a $0.04 after tax gain when we exited the hedged position. Consistent with what we discussed in our investor conference earlier this year, we continue to be interested in natural gas infrastructure opportunities.
The Customer Supply and Proprietary Power and Gas Trading businesses were down by $0.04 relative to the prior year, primarily due to lower contributions from power and gas trading. As we have said before, opportunities in this part of the business fluctuate based on a number of factors. And while last year's quarter was up $0.07 compared to 2008, this year's third quarter did not have as many opportunities for us to pursue. To be consistent with the information we provide to you on a gross margin hedged slide, GEXA is included in customer supply businesses for presentation of comparable earnings. The customer supply businesses continue to do very well on a year-to-date basis.
All other factors were negative 5%, $0.05 primarily due to higher interest expense. Although our expected gross margin is very well hedged, the current commodity price backdrop has an impact on our business. It's manifest itself in two ways. First in a portion of our existing assets that is un-contracted and un-hedged, which is roughly 8% of our existing asset gross margin in 2011 and 17% in 2012. Secondly, as we have discussed before, it is one of several items that affects counterparty's interest in signing long-term contracts for renewable generation. Since the forecasts we presented at the investor conference in May of this year, the 10-year natural gas strip has declined 16% while a 2011 calendar strip has declined by 21%. In the near term, our open gross margin is relatively modest and as such, there's not much of a significant direct effect on our gross margin as it relates to our existing assets. But there is some impact. Additionally, indirectly, the lower power and gas prices affect our expectations around the currently on un-contracted wind assets that we expect to contract under long-term power purchase agreements.
Let me discuss that in a little more detail as we turn to our hedging status for 2011 and 2012 and expect that equivalent gross margins. Over the last couple of years, we have increased the percentage of our business that is hedged in the near term mainly as a result of what we believe would be more uncertain commodity price environment. In addition, we continue to take steps to minimize the risks and improve the visibility of the earnings and cash flow profile for the portfolio. As I mentioned earlier, contracts that were effective this year on approximately 1190 megawatts representing both light and market sub- 750 helped earnings for the quarter. Additionally, since the beginning of 2008, we have signed approximately 2110 megawatts of wind PPAs and approximately 350 megawatts of solar PPAs. For 2011, we are 92% hedged on expected equivalent gross margin on our existing assets. 
Across all of the energy resources businesses, the midpoint of our total expected equivalent gross margin has decreased by approximately 155 million since the second quarter. I do not focus too much on this midpoint, but I know that many of you do, so I have chosen a tier as a frame of reference. The three main drivers of this decrease are in new asset additions and our existing wind assets and in our power and gas trading business. As we do every year at this time, we have moved the new assets expected to be in service by the end of 2010, up to the appropriate categories of existing assets and so what you see now in the new investment line are the expected results of the asset we expect to place in service in 2011.
For these 2011 asset additions, our gross margin estimate is down approximately $65 million since the second quarter due primarily to lower estimated CITC elections associated with reduced new-build wind assumptions and solar assumptions. Net of the positive impact of the 2010 asset additions that moved into existing assets, the contracted wind assets gross margin is down approximately $35 million primarily due to the sustained lower power and natural gas prices on un-contracted assets that I spoke about just a minute ago. Finally, the power and gas trading business is down roughly $55 million due to our expectation in the near term that the volatility and low price environment will mean that there are less opportunities for this business.
Turning to the 2012 gross margin, we're 83% hedged and expected equivalent gross margin on our existing assets. Although there are many puts and takes when comparing 2011 to 2012, I wanted to highlight a few of the more significant items. Please note that we did not include the impact of any new wind or solar generation than we expect to build in 2012. Although the operating earnings impact for the new investments put in place in 2012 could be modest as a result of the expected commissioning dates, we do expect to qualify for CITC on a good portion of our 2012 wind and solar development, but that margin is not included in this slide.
As we did last year, we will add 2012 new asset information as the year gets closer. In the new investment line, you will only see the full earnings impact from the new wind and solar assets we expect to build in 2011. Our contracted wind segment is expected to be down roughly $20 million compared to 2011, which is roughly the difference between the expiration of PTCs and expected PPA price and a new contract for the currently un-contracted asset as well as PPA price increases embedded in our current PPAs.
Our contracted other segment is expected to be roughly flat due to the full year effect of the upgrade we expect to complete at our Point Beach nuclear facility in Wisconsin in 2011, net of the expiration of some power sales contracts on two of our gas fire facilities in the north east. Our hedged wind and merchant northeast other categories are expected to be down approximately $45 million each due to the rolloff of higher-priced hedges. Our Gas Infrastructure business reflects our shale gas drilling program and the majority of this margin is currently hedged. The targets for the customer supply business in power and gas trading reflect the modest increase over reduced 2011 expectations.
I would like to provide a brief update on our wind development plans for the remainder of 2010 and 2011. For 2010, we currently have approximately 680 megawatts of new wind already in service or under construction and likely to be commissioned although some megawatts may roll over to the first part of 2011. We are mindful that this is likely the toughest wind development market in some time. For 2011, we remain cautiously optimistic that we will add between 700 to 1000 megawatts of wind generation. Although we have had some success this year in signing long-term PPAs, we continue to see some sluggishness as it relates to securing long-term PPAs. At the same time, we are seeing reductions in the cost of build of new wind projects so the average economic returns we are expecting are still attractive.
We would like to provide a little more clarity on 2010 and 2011 adjusted EPS guidance. Based on our assumption that the settlement agreement will be approved for 2010, we expect adjusted earnings per share to be within the lower half of our previous disclosed range of $4.25 to $4.65. In the quarter, FPL lowered its surplus depreciation amortization, which has the effect of increasing net depreciation expense by approximately $0.12 of adjusted EPS. This reduction is consistent with the settlement agreement. Looking at the longer-term picture though, the current reduction in earnings as a result of higher depreciation expense in 2010 provides us a bit more certainty regarding our 2012 earnings and returns at FPL. If the settlement agreement is ultimately rejected, which we believe to be a low probability based on the support it is receiving from interveners, 2010 results would be at the high end of the original range due in large part to additional surplus depreciation and amortization, which FPL would likely record.
Turning now to 2011. We last indicated that our 2011 adjusted earnings would be roughly in line with the 2010 range. Since then we've had a number of positive and negative developments that affect our adjusted earnings per share expectations. On the positive side, the rate case settlement agreement would allow for substantial recovery of West County unit 3 in 2011 on a cash basis. However, at energy resources, the factors that I've just discussed related to 2011 gross margin have negatively affected the earnings outlook.
First, as we noted in the updated 2011 gross margin estimates, we are now expecting fewer CITC elections than we previously expected. This revision is a result of our view that the wind development market will continue to be challenging next year. Second, based simply on the fact that we have some un-contracted wind assets in a declining commodity price environment, we need to reduce gross margin expectations. In addition, the timing of expected PPAs has been slightly extended. And third, we think there should be reduced expectations related to our proprietary trading business in 2011 as we have shown you before, these businesses go into the year largely un-hedged unlike our existing assets. And it makes sense for us to reduce expectations in this area based on what we perceive as the near-term opportunities in the market.
Incorporating all of these factors, we now believe that we can narrow the range of our 2011 adjusted earnings per share estimate to between $4.25 and $4.55. We continue to feel comfortable with the 5% to 7% average annual increase in adjusted EPS through 2014 from a 2009 base although we do not expect that average to necessarily be the actual increase in each year-to-year period. We also continue to be open to asset acquisitions that fit our portfolio and investment profile and there are quite a number of those opportunities at this time. While we look at most opportunities, we remain committed to our disciplined approach to capital deployment. Over time, we strive to be in a strong financial position which enables us to take advantage of those opportunities that meet our criteria. As always, these potential opportunities are not reflected in the specific development targets we have provided to you.
To summarize the 2010 third quarter on an adjusted basis, FPL contributed $0.74 per share, Energy resources contributed $0.64 per share and Corporate and Other contributed $0.07 per share primarily as result of an adjustment related to previously deferred taxes. That is a total of $1.45 compared to $1.38 per share in the 2009 third quarter or about a 5% increase year-over-year. Thank you for listening. And with that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said before, when we go into these decisions on a year ahead basis, we're trying to deploy capital either where we already have a long-term power purchase agreement which we do for roughly 250 megawatts or so of the 2011 development plan. But
componenttext: Well, as we said before, when we go into these decisions on a year ahead basis, we're trying to deploy capital either where we already have a long-term power purchase agreement which we do for roughly 250 megawatts or so of the 2011 development plan. But we try to do it in those areas where we think there's a high likelihood either before construction begins during construction or short time afterward that we will get a Power Purchase Agreement. That is not changed. I've talked about that a little bit before. Many of our projects do not have a long-term Power Purchase Agreement when we begin. In the past, many of them did have a Power Purchase Agreement where we expected to get a Power Purchase Agreement by the time construction ended. But here in the last 12 to 18 months, the process has been a little slower. So it doesn't mean we're not going to deploy capital if we don't have a long-term Power Purchase Agreement in hand. But it does mean we're going to be a little bit more cautious than we have in the past because it has taken a little longer in some cases to get an agreement than we originally believed.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, there's a couple of ways to actually qualify for CITC in '11 and '12, right? One of them is a Safe Harbor provision in the rules and the other one is actually the start of construction. We're going to use both of those to qualify a majority of our pr
componenttext: Dan, there's a couple of ways to actually qualify for CITC in '11 and '12, right? One of them is a Safe Harbor provision in the rules and the other one is actually the start of construction. We're going to use both of those to qualify a majority of our projects, wind and solar projects in '11 and '12 and for solar, actually in '13 and 14. We've talked about the Genesis project, obviously, there are others that we have in our pipeline that we have not discussed. And that's something that we pay a lot of attention to. As you can imagine, it's the leader in the industry. We have access to and have been able to have discussions with a lot of folks that are writing these rules. So at this point, we feel fairly comfortable that a significant portion of our development plans in '11 and '12 for wind, and '13 and '14 for solar will qualify for CITC.

componenttext: I mean, it'd be fair to assume anything that you think is fair, but we're not going to comment on what we believe the ROE would be. We may in the future, but clearly at the settlement agreement is approved, we would be required to stay within the 9% to 11%. If we're under and this is in the agreement, if we're under the 11%, we would have to use amortization as a depreciation credit to get us up, that doesn't necessarily mean that we have to get to 11%. If we are over 11%, we would not be able to use any depreciation credit to keep us over 11%. And let me just kind of go back on something I just said because the last part of it, I misspoke on the first part. If we‚Äôre under 9% were required to amortization credit to get us up to 9%. And if we're over 11%. We can't use any to keep us over 11%.

componenttextpreview: No, I was trying to answer another question and I thought Dan was trying to get to. I think a presumption by investors and analyst, the midpoint of 10% was in our previous guidance I think is appropriate. You're trying to link that previous guidance in, i
componenttext: No, I was trying to answer another question and I thought Dan was trying to get to. I think a presumption by investors and analyst, the midpoint of 10% was in our previous guidance I think is appropriate. You're trying to link that previous guidance in, i.e. at 10% and also 2011 earnings. Let me kind of explain it this way and maybe it will be helpful to you and others on the call. The amount of gross margin reduction for what I'll call the lower build in 2011 for both wind and solar is roughly $0.10 and you can take the gross margin number, you can tax affect it, it's roughly $0.10 and again that'd be a reduction. The reduction in the lower commodity prices from due to our un-contract wind assets and it's slightly extending the term of the merchant time that those projects will be in a merchant state is roughly $0.07. The reduction in trading, power and gas trading proprietary power and gas trading that I mentioned in 2011 is also $0.07. In this call, I also said that the amount of fuel savings attributable to West County 3 are roughly in line with but slightly less than the revenue requirements, which is roughly--a revenue requirements are roughly $100 million. If you add all that together, and again, I'm going just from the revenue line, I'm not really focused on the bottom end, but if you add all that together, you'll roughly to get a net $0.10 deduction from whatever midpoint you started with. If you add all that together, what we've actually done is we brought the midpoint down of our 2011 guidance down $0.05 from $4.45 to $4.40. That's the way I look at it.

componenttext: If I'd say the midpoint of your current 2011 earnings guidance? And I presume that, that assumes that you earn 10% ROE at the utility more or less, and if you're at the midpoint of the gross margin guidance range for the merchant power business as a starting point?

componenttextpreview: I think that is the question, Greg, asked. I think the assumption of using 10% is a reasonable assumption, what I was trying to point out, to Greg, is that the range is -- to Dan, that the range is 9% to 11% and if we get under 9%, we'd be required to use
componenttext: I think that is the question, Greg, asked. I think the assumption of using 10% is a reasonable assumption, what I was trying to point out, to Greg, is that the range is -- to Dan, that the range is 9% to 11% and if we get under 9%, we'd be required to use amortization to get up to 9%. Now in my comments today, I also indicated that we had not taken any depreciation credit year to date for 2010. And we can use a total of $776 million during the three year period of the pending settlement agreement. So I don't think I have to connect the dots necessarily, but that should give everyone an indication of where the ROE range would be and would be a little smaller than 9% to 11% for 2011.

componenttext: Steve, this is Lew. I just wanted to comment about the uncertainty on wind and I‚Äôve said that it's clearly a tougher market right now than what we might have experienced a few years ago, but I want to point out that even in the sloppiest times of the wind market, we didn't have 250 megawatts of PPAs as of the end of the third quarter that when we're looking out at the next year. So some of you who aren‚Äôt familiar with the wind development business, I mean a lot of times we would have a lot of things in the works but we didn't have deals signed up at that point. And so I would not -- I want to make sure nobody's looking at what we just reported as being a big negative. It's a tough market out there, but we gave you our estimate as to what we're seeing and I think you could argue there's more variability about it then maybe what was happening in the frothiest markets. But we have a fair amount of visibility and so I wouldn't discount the guidance we just gave you.

componenttext: No. There's two numbers, right? There's currently constructed and on contracted as roughly 350 megawatts. It's a little less than that. The last time I'd mentioned that number, it was 400 megawatts. The amount that we would expect to have at the end of the year i.e. because you're referring to 680 megawatts, some of those 680 megawatts do not have current contracts. So unless and it could, but unless something -- unless we get a contract by the end of the year on some of those projects, at the end of the year, we'll roughly have 700 megawatts of un-contracted wind plants that had been constructed. And that's different just kind of add to that, we have roughly 1700 megawatts of un-contracted, but hedged the wind projects out in Texas. Now when we built those, those weren't ever expected to be contracted. So the 700 that I'm talking about for the end of the year are those that we do expect to get contracts on, but we do not have contracts on or we do not expect to have contracts on at the end of the year. Is that helpful?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the utility, I wanted to ask something about what your comments on customers and growth. And I noticed you changed the presentation this quarter to look at -- to the trailing '12 customers rather than sequential quarter, but as we look ba
componenttext: And then just on the utility, I wanted to ask something about what your comments on customers and growth. And I noticed you changed the presentation this quarter to look at -- to the trailing '12 customers rather than sequential quarter, but as we look back to June, and look back you only added maybe 3,000 customers in the third quarter, which is obviously slow down can you talk about that a little?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Historically, probably, or I don't know, towards the end of 2008 or 2009, before that time, we had always shown this customer growth chart the way you're seeing it now. We compared the average customers this quarter to the average customers to the ye
componenttext: Yes. Historically, probably, or I don't know, towards the end of 2008 or 2009, before that time, we had always shown this customer growth chart the way you're seeing it now. We compared the average customers this quarter to the average customers to the year ago quarter, we had always done that so when we got to the period of significant customer reductions or at least significant for us, we wanted to provide investors some additional information because it was almost -- it was less meaningful to look at what happened a year ago when we were getting significant changes every month. And so for the last probably 12 to 18 months or it might be a little shorter than that, we switched over to let‚Äôs just tell you what's happened with the sequential quarters. Now you might argue with us, I think we've got a little more stability now and because we have a little more stability now, and because we have a little more stability now and because we have a little more stability now, we've kind of gone back to what we were doing before, because I think it is a better comparison than just a sequential quarter and primarily because of the seasonality in the business. So that's why we've gone back to it. To answer your question, one of your questions, we have on a sequential basis about 3000 more customers at the end of September 2010 than we had at June of 2010.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just felt like it was on a slowing pace rather than I kind of continued improvement. Maybe that's just the seasonality.
componenttext: I just felt like it was on a slowing pace rather than I kind of continued improvement. Maybe that's just the seasonality.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: It absolutely is the seasonality. If I go back to at least a rough number is not a year ago September on sequential basis, we had lost 2,000 customers in 2008 September again a sequential basis we had lost 11,000 customers in September of '07 but things w
componenttext: It absolutely is the seasonality. If I go back to at least a rough number is not a year ago September on sequential basis, we had lost 2,000 customers in 2008 September again a sequential basis we had lost 11,000 customers in September of '07 but things were still going pretty darn good on a sequential basis, we'd only added 10,000 customers. So I'm not necessarily disappointed by the 3000 customers. I'm pretty happy with the 27,000 quarter-to-quarter. We haven't seen that type of quarter-to quarter grow, 27,000, sense since the June '08 quarter.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ted, you did hear it correctly. And the reason for that is under -- if the settlement isn‚Äôt approved which by the way I think truly mean this and absolute travesty for our customers in Florida because it is a great deal to have these fixed rates through
componenttext: Ted, you did hear it correctly. And the reason for that is under -- if the settlement isn‚Äôt approved which by the way I think truly mean this and absolute travesty for our customers in Florida because it is a great deal to have these fixed rates through the end of 2012. The settlement is not approved because of the significant positive weather that we've had this year, and you go back to the rate case settlement and again if the settlement is not approved we deal with her motion for the reconsideration, but let's put that aside for a second, the very real issue for us-- we think that's the winnable pace for us but putting that aside, if you go back to the rate case, you essentially would have to amortize $224 million on a pretax basis, that's a credit to depreciation expense for the entire year on a pretax basis. In addition to the favorable weather that we've had at Florida Power& Light company which is roughly $0.17, $0.18, $0.19 on a year-to-date basis. So you can see that when you put all that together, you would get towards a very high end of the 425 to 465 range. Let me that it's not what I'd like to see, that is not what we're hoping for.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I guess, that highlights the fact that the settlement allows you some flexibility and essentially your -- and in indirect ways, you're banking the good weather and it's actually while '10 will be coming down, that lever will be available for you in ei
componenttext: But I guess, that highlights the fact that the settlement allows you some flexibility and essentially your -- and in indirect ways, you're banking the good weather and it's actually while '10 will be coming down, that lever will be available for you in either '11 or '12 to help facilitate earnings growth.

componenttext: You should think of it solely as the fuel savings from West County 3. componenttext: But it seems like if those are the real drivers, if $0.14 is really related to the fuel, it looks like maybe you're saving most of your dry power on the amortization side until '12 is kind of what I'm getting at. It seems like this will allow you to kind of have a significant or a decent growth rate at the utility with all of the accounting mechanisms and fuel savings and stuff like. Is that a good way to think about it?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I guess, I think about it just a little differently, Ted. This is a great deal for our customers. And it provides them significant stability, financial stability all the way through the end of 2012 and it continues to allow us to put some assets that
componenttext: Well I guess, I think about it just a little differently, Ted. This is a great deal for our customers. And it provides them significant stability, financial stability all the way through the end of 2012 and it continues to allow us to put some assets that will longer term saver customers a lot of money. In return for that, the settlement provides some financial stability for us during these times and potentially keep us from filing a new rate case during these times. So there's clearly some puts and takes in the agreement. Overall as I've said before and as Lew has said before, this is a positive both for our customers and for the company and it does provide both stability through 2012.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add just for 2012 utility, is you also have the full year impact of West County 3, not just the half year impact and you also have the benefit of both the operates as well as the PVC on Canavaral and Riviera. So there are several g
componenttext: The other thing I would add just for 2012 utility, is you also have the full year impact of West County 3, not just the half year impact and you also have the benefit of both the operates as well as the PVC on Canavaral and Riviera. So there are several growth drivers for utility in 2012 versus 2011.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Analyst Day, when you talked about the 5% to 7% growth rate through ‚Äò14, it seemed like you are actually kind of saying, that was conservative and that if you did the math, you could potentially exceed that. With the adjustments that you've made
componenttext: On the Analyst Day, when you talked about the 5% to 7% growth rate through ‚Äò14, it seemed like you are actually kind of saying, that was conservative and that if you did the math, you could potentially exceed that. With the adjustments that you've made to the near term forecast, is that still valid or you now kind of feeling that the 5% to 7% is less conservative?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I didn't say conservative. I think the questions that were presented was well g-wiz, you've got  a growth rate of earnings that FPL of XY, you've got a growth rate of energy resources going from X to Y, and what I said was you've got also account for
componenttext: Yes, I didn't say conservative. I think the questions that were presented was well g-wiz, you've got  a growth rate of earnings that FPL of XY, you've got a growth rate of energy resources going from X to Y, and what I said was you've got also account for the fact that we've got dilution, we got other expenses going into this. But I felt comfortable with the 5% to 7%. It was clearly towards the high end but I also said that there was a significant amount of execution to do that from 2010 to 2014 and that I was concerned with the state of the economy. What's happened since then is -- some of those things that kind of played themselves out. We're now talking about reduced build at least from what we had in our plan next year, although we're still in the range of 700 to 1000 megawatts of wind. So some of those things have kind of played out. Now is not the time for me to discuss whether we are at the top end or at the bottom end. We feel comfortable with the range that we provided and I'll repeat what I said back then that in this economy, there remains a significant amount of execution risks on part, but as I look at the details of the capital investments that we have to make both at the Florida Power & Light Company side and at the energy resources side, including transmission development in Texas, I feel pretty -- I feel like there's some pretty darn good opportunities for us to invest capital at some very attractive rates from now through 2014. And so I feel comfortable with a range but we shouldn't forget that they're still execution risk.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Jim Robo, again. Let me just add that there have been several questions around ‚Äò13 and ‚Äò14 and I think it's important to remember and our just mentioned one of the drivers for '13 and '14 which is the transmission to $800 million of transmissi
componenttext: This is Jim Robo, again. Let me just add that there have been several questions around ‚Äò13 and ‚Äò14 and I think it's important to remember and our just mentioned one of the drivers for '13 and '14 which is the transmission to $800 million of transmission investment in Texas. But we have $2.5 billion of solar investment that is about to become under construction with signed contracts that come online in '13 and '14. Those are significant earnings drivers for energy resources in the '13 and '14 period. And aren‚Äôt reflected in anything you see in the 2011 and 2012 charts.

componenttextpreview: This is Armando Olivera. It is currently scheduled for the November 9th agenda conference. So all the matters that have been deferred have now been brought forward and put on that agenda and it would be a function of whether the district court of appeals
componenttext: This is Armando Olivera. It is currently scheduled for the November 9th agenda conference. So all the matters that have been deferred have now been brought forward and put on that agenda and it would be a function of whether the district court of appeals has ruled by that date or not. If it doesn't rule by that date, there's several more dates left in the year and of course, the commission could always opt to have a special agenda to get this approved. And we feel pretty good. There's a lot -- all the parties really are pretty actively supporting the agreement and asking the commission to vote on it as soon as possible.

componenttext: And then back to the other Armando, on the wind slide, you talked about construction cost coming down, just maybe give us a little clarity on that, how that plays into construction cost?

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've seen really since 2008, we've seen construction cost in this industry come down. I would continue to say as I've said before that there is more downward pressure on cost than there is upward pressure. Here over, I'd say the last six to nine mo
componenttext: Well, we've seen really since 2008, we've seen construction cost in this industry come down. I would continue to say as I've said before that there is more downward pressure on cost than there is upward pressure. Here over, I'd say the last six to nine months, I've seen some pretty significant decreases. There is still differences as we've mentioned before in different regions of the country that the West particularly the California region is generally more expensive than the Midwest or some other areas that we're building. But if we were to put together the same kind of example that we put together for investors before, which is generally a Midwest type of example, I think the last time Midwest type of cash flow earnings example, I think the last time we put it together, the range, the KW range is somewhere between 1800 and 2000. If I were to put that together now, the range would probably be 1600 to 1800. So I mean, we are seeing cost decreases, and that's very helpful when you're dealing with a challenging environment because it allows you to protect the earnings that you expect from these investments.

headline: NextEra Energy, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On a quarterly basis, we go through and we take a look at that business just like we do many of our other businesses. In this particular circumstance, we had hedged the wells or we had hedged the expected production from the wells. And as we looked at the
componenttext: On a quarterly basis, we go through and we take a look at that business just like we do many of our other businesses. In this particular circumstance, we had hedged the wells or we had hedged the expected production from the wells. And as we looked at the economics in a declining natural gas environment, we believe that it made more sense for us to take the capital that we had allocated to those wells and put it to use in other places and so that meant that we were able to flatten out the hedges and when we flattened out the hedges, at least internally, we take all of our documentation pretty seriously. These are non-qualifying hedges, which may not mean a whole heck of a lot to you, but sort of like internal hedge accounting and our documentation once we flattened out the hedges for these particular hedges required us to take the gain in this case. It would have required us to take the loss, so there was a loss, but it was a gain and we made the right economic decision and we moved on. This was a small -- it was $0.04 or so for the quarter but it was a small subset of wells that we were dealing with. It's a business that we've continue to be very happy to be in and with the hedges that we have in place, we feel pretty good about the remaining investment that's not to say that in the future we may not change our mind on some of those. But it's a business that we've got heck of a lot of knowledge from as well as some pretty good returns on.
